Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Large-Scale Wave Energy Arrays -- Integrated Control/Array Design in Random Seas

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Scruggs, Jeffrey / Taflanidis, Alexandros
Proposal Number: 1235732 / 1235768
Institution: University of Michigan Ann Arbor / University of Notre Dame
Title: Collaborative Research: Large-Scale Wave Energy Arrays -- Integrated Control/Array Design in Random Seas

In the transition of the US energy economy from traditional technologies to renewables, ocean wave energy technology has a signiﬁcant role to play. However, our understanding of how to best harness the resource is still evolving. For Wave Energy Conversion (WEC) technologies to be relevant on a utility scale, it will be necessary to distribute vast arrays of energy-harvesting buoys across a wide expanse of ocean. Maximization of power generation from large-scale WEC arrays requires a synthesis of optimal control and optimal geometry techniques. The present state-of-understanding is limited to single buoys and small array sizes. It also does not account for the limitations of power conversion systems, or the fact that sea states are random and uncertain phenomena. This collaborative project constitutes an eﬀort to rectify these issues, through a novel synthesis of two disparate research threads: robust control theory and large-scale stochastic optimization.

The proposed work will focus on accurate techniques for assessing and optimizing the power generation potential for a given geographic location and a given array perimeter. This will provide answers to some necessary questions for this technology to move forward: (i) Given an array perimeter, a probabilistic characterization of the sea state, and a technological characterization of the generators, what is the optimal number of WEC buoys, and how should they be arranged? (ii) How do the optimal number of buoys and conﬁguration depend on the conversion technology used? (iii) How does the buoy conﬁguration depend on the eﬃciency of energy storage and transmission systems that interface the array with the grid? The PIs will integrate their respective approaches (the optimal power generation control algorithm for a WEC system, and stochastic sampling methods) into a single computationally-eﬃcient framework, which simultaneously reshapes the array and redesigns the controller upon each iteration. This will reduce the time necessary to accurately evaluate the maximum power generation capability for a given array size by several orders of magnitude. In this work the PIs will innovate generic techniques for large-scale WEC array design using techniques from robust control theory and advances in high-performance computing.

This collaborative project will provide a clear insight into the true potential of large-scale WEC arrays to meet future energy needs. Also the project has the potential to lift technology adoption barriers and to promote advocacy among the public. This will be accomplished via diﬀusion mechanisms that enhance ambassadorship among students and awareness among stakeholders. The PIs will adopt a two-pronged strategy, involving: 1. development of open-access online resource assessment software, and 2. educational outreach initiatives focused on ocean energy. In the ﬁrst component, the online application, supported by a friendly user-interface, will assess the optimized annual power output and array conﬁguration for a user-speciﬁed geographic location and array perimeter. A more technical oﬄine version targeted at WEC developers will also be made freely available. The second component will be achieved through interdisciplinary REU initiatives that target underrepresented groups and through the development of project-based learning modules, leveraging the proposed online assessment tools. This will motivate and empower the student participants to advance this research both within their profession and the public at large, thus propagating the broader impacts of this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ocean wave energy constitutes a promising and abundant source of renewable energy, and has a significant role to play as our nation transitions to more sustainable power generation technologies.  However, technologies for maximizing the usefulness of this resource are still evolving. One of the general paradigms for wave energy converter (WEC) technology is comprised of an array of floating buoys, each coupled to a generator, spread across a large ocean footprint. In such configurations, the buoys must be optimally controlled to maximize the average power they absorb from the waves, and this power maximization is also strongly dependent on the geometry of the array configuration.

This work has led to a much more complete understanding of the optimal usage of WEC buoy arrays, both in terms of their control, and their configuration, to maximize their effective renewable energy source. Researchers at the University of Michigan focused primarily on the investigation of optimal control strategies, and collaborated with researchers at the University of Notre Dame on the study of array geometry. 

At the start of the project, the optimal control of WEC arrays was well-understood only for situations where waves were assumed to oscillate at a single frequency. However, realistic ocean waves are random, and the power flux is spread across a wide spectrum of frequencies. This project has resulted in a technique for optimizing the control of power generation from WEC arrays, when subjected to these random environments.

Additionally, optimal control systems for WEC arrays typically assume that it is possible to accurately forecast ocean waves so that the control actions of the generators can be made in a way that anticipates a wave’s future behavior. Although there are technologies for determining future wave loadings explicitly (e.g., using up-wave sensors), this technology is unproven and still somewhat speculative. In this project the researchers developed mathematical techniques to optimize the control actions of the generators, subject to the constraint of causality. This leads to a considerably more practical design technique, while achieving power generation performance that is almost as good as the case where the future waves are actually known.

In developing these results, there were considerable analytical challenges that had to be resolved, to make the techniques applicable to realistic WEC arrays. For example, it was necessary that the techniques be robust to uncertainty in the dynamical behavior, and layout configuration, of the array. Also, techniques needed to be developed whereby the control decisions made by a given generator could be made using knowledge of the responses of only nearby WECS, not the entire array. Moreover, the effects of nonlinear dynamics needed to be properly accounted and compensated for, as well as the effects of finite stroke length of the generators.

The final outcome of this project is a set of tools that may be useful to many stakeholders in the burgeoning wave energy industry in the United States, both for the purposes of resource assessment and site scoping, as well as for optimal design.
